titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.28 Richmond, Va. Monday, February 2, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents per week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: A fight on the Blackwater — the enemy repulsed with Heavy loss.
div3.p:
An official dispatch, received by Gen. G. W. Smith, says that Gen. Pryer was attacked Saturday, eight miles from Suffolk, by the enemy, (reported by prisoners ten to fifteen thousand strong.) After a hard fight of three hours the enemy was repulsed with very heavy loss.
Gen. Pryor, at last accounts, hold the entire battle-field, and the enemy was in full retreat.
Our loss was considerable.
Among the killed is the gallant Col. Poage, of Virginia.

div3.head: The murder of Rev. Dr. Boyd.
div3.p:
In the short notice of the death of this eminent minister, published in our last, we were unable to give any of the particulars connected with the affair.
We have siren been informed that he was shot whilst approaching the Yankee picket.
The report states that he was called by the sentinel, and not hearing the order, or regarding it, he was fired upon and almost instantly killed.

A correspondent of the Knoxville Register, giving some account of the achievements of the cavalry under Gen. Pogram, which supported the right of Gen. Breckenridge's division, officer a high compliment for his conduct on the field.
He also notices especially, for their gallantry, Lieut. Tucker Randolph and R. T. Daniel, A. A. General to the Brigade, of this city.

div3.head: New Orleans Gossip.
div3.p:
--Under this head the Crisis gives the substance of recent information derived from a lady who lately left New Orleans, after having vainly sought, for three months, to obtain a passport.
We subjoin extracts:
The administration of Banks differs but little from that of Butler, both of them being tyrants, fanatics, robbers, and Massachusetts Yankees.

Although no information of a reliable character of Southern affairs is allowed to see the light through the papers of that city, yet our people there are kept fully advised of the success of our arms.
Southern papers find their way in from time to time, and the information is circulated from hand to hand.

The Federal troops are, to a considerable extent, seriously dissatisfied with the service and with the war, especially the Irish portion of them.
The better class of Federal officers do not hesitate to declare themselves disgusted with such a service.
They do not expect to hold New Orleans permanently, nor to conquer the South, and they regard the temporary occupation of the city as important only to those cormorants who are sucking blood from a subjected people.

A few weeks before the departure of Butler a spirited engraving representing Butler's face very securately, with the head and body of a hyena in the act of tearing open the graves of Gen. A. S. Johnston and others, which graves had been violated and robbed, was sent to Gen. Butler with the compliments of the people of New Orleans.

Spies upon the Confederate war movements are constantly traveling between Mississippi and New Orleans.
They often pass our lines and stations for hundreds of miles, without a single inquiry or examination of any kind by our officials.
The people of that city were much surprised a few days ago by the presence of a Confederate officer, engaged a few months since in the conscripting service in Mississippi, who seemed to be on intimate terms with the Federal officers.
The community there could not learn whether he came down under a flag of truce, or on what conditions he was permitted to enter the city and depart at his leisure.
He left the city last week and said he was going to Texas.
The Federal commanders at New Orleans seemed to be kept fully advised of all our movements, the strength of our forces, and the character of our defences.

Butler said there were but two brave men in New Orleans, and they were Father Mullen, of the Jesuit Church, and Doctor Stone, the celebrated Surgeon.
Father Mullen refused to take the oath, and denounced the tyranny that required it of him, and set them at defiance.
Father Monaghan, of the Catholic Church, denounces Federal tyranny from his pulpit, and declares if they arrest him it must be at the altar, and before they drag him to the door they must wade knee-deep in blood, Dr. Nesux also refuses to attend the Yankee sick or wounded upon any condition.

There are now very few Federal troops in New Orleans.
Those who guard the approaches to the city have frequent battles with our patriotic partisans, who are sometimes badly worsted.

div3.head: A Daring woman.
div3.p:
--The editor of the Winchaster (Tennessee) Bulletin, on a trip South, recently saw, among other novelties.
Mrs.-- dressed up a la militaire, who had a furlough to visit Atlanta.
This woman soldier is a member of the Louisiana cavalry, and "in for the war." She is about twenty years of age, rather small, and tolerably good looking.
Her husband was killed at Shilch, and she forthwith took his place in the ranks.
She has been twice wounded in battle, and in one of the battles taken prisoner, and regularly exchanged.

Specie and Bank Notes.--The demand, for Gold has abated, and brokers are now generally asking $2,20. For large sums a deduction would be made.
The buying rates are $2.25@2.10.
Silver has advanced, in consequence of a better demand and various orders from North Carolina.
The rates, however, are irregular, varying from $1.90@2.10 --buying and selling.
Virginia and North Carolina Bank notes are selling at 35 cents; Georgia and South Carolina at 40 cents premium.
Northern Exchange 1.40; Sterling do. 2.20.

Bonds and Stocks.--Confederate bonds ($100,000.000 loan) are in demand at par and interest; do. do. ($10,000,000 loan) at $109, and interest — very little of the latter offering.
State bonds are lower.
We quote Virginia sixes registered at $105 --the price at which they are now offered; N. Carolina sixes $128½ @ $129; do. eighths $116 and interest; Missouri sixes $120; Tennessee do., $119; Richmond City bonds $125; Exchange Bank stock $103; Traders' Bank $105; Bank of Richmond 80; Richmond and Danville R. R.
stock $105½ Va. Central R. R.
do. $75; Richmond Railway do. $53.

div4.p:
The following quotations are based generally upon the wholesale prices at the stores.
Retail prices are fixed according to the views of dealers.

Apples--The market is not very well supplied.
We quote at $35 @10 bbl.
Bacon.--In great demand at 75@80 cts for hoground.
Bread.--Pilot, 15 cts lb; Water and Butter Crackers, 18 cts; Soda Crackers, 25 cts. These are the prices at Tinsley's bakery.
Butter.--$1.40@1.50 cts lb. A very fine article would bring more.
Cheese.--We continue to quote at $1.25@1.50 lb. for home manufactured.
Dried Fruit.--Apples $5@3; Peaches $10@12 bushel.
Hay.--Baled, $5 cwt; Oats, $5; Shucks, $3.50.
Onions.--$1t@50 per bbl.

Potatoes,--Irish, $1 bus. No Sweet in market.
Would command high prices.

Seeds.--No change.
Clover, $27 @ 30 bush.

Tobacco.--Market firm.
Lugs $10@ 5; Common Leaf $15 @20; Fine $25@12.
These quotations are from last sales at the Exchange.

Corn.--Very scarce.
We continue to quote at $3.75 bushel.
Corn Meal.--In demand at $3.75 @$4 bush.
Flour.--Superfine, $20; Extra, $22; Family, $15. If prices were based upon Government rates Superfine would be quoted at $17.50.

Oats.--None in market.
Last sales, $3 bush.

Wheat.--This article is unchanged.
Market quiet at $3.40 @$3.50 for best qualities of red and white.
Coffee.--$1@$1.25 lb. Retail price, $5.
Molasses.--Sales at $10 per gallon, which is a decline.
Sugar.--Brown, in hhds., 80 @ 90; in bbls., 90 @$1, as to quality.
Salt.--25 lb.
Lard.--$1 lb., and in demand.
Rice.--12½c. lb., by the tierce.
Liquors.--Whiskey, $27 gallon, but a very prime article will bring $30; Apple Brandy, $21; very little French Brandy in market, though we note sales by D. S. Ruffard at $45 gallon.
Cotton Yarns.--$8 @$8.50 lb., by the pad.
Shot.--We quote from recent sales $1@$1.25 lb.
Candles.--Tallow, 90 @$1 lb.

div3.p: New York papers of the 29th inst., have been received.

The Times contains the address of Joe Hooker to the army of the Potomac.
We copy from this address the following very modest assertion:

q.p:
"In equipment, intelligence, and valor, the enemy is our interior.
Let us never hesitate to give him battle wherever we can find him."

div3.p: The only movement on Tuesday was a change of locality for the headquarters.

The prisoners of the Arkansas Post have been sent to St. Louis.
There are among them General Churchill, ten Colonels, ten Lieut.-Colonels, ten Majors, one hundred Captains, two hundred Lieutenants, and some thirty or forty Adjutants, Staff officers, Quartermasters, Surgeons, old., making a total of about 5,000.
The troops are said to be all from Texas.
The Ohio and Mississippi rivers are falling.
An expedition comprising three gunboats and a number of transports, under command of General Foster, called from Hatteras Inlet on Saturday, 24th ult. Destination supposed to be Wilmington.

Another expedition was fitting out with much dispatch and would sell soon.
Probably, says the Times, it has the same destination.
It will comprise the entire command of Gen. Nagies.
It has been ascertained by Gen. Foster that 7',000 rebel troops have been sent into North Carolina from the Rappahannock.

News had been received at Key West that the rebel steamer Oreta had got out of Mobile, and captured a Boston brig, from Cuba, on the 17th off Tortugas, loaded with sugar.
She was sunk by order of the rebel Captain Maffit.
The Oreto had reached Havana with 1,700 bales of cotton.

It was understood as certain at New Orleans that the vessel which sunk the Hatteras was the pirate Alabama.
The fight was very severe, and the Hatteras went down with her flag flying — Bloody clothing was found in the vicinity of the fight, but it is not known what was the fate of the crew.

Port Royal dates to the 29th had been received at New York.
Gen. Hunter had arrived out and assumed command.
The indications were that an active campaign would at once commence, and it was probable that Savannah would be attacked before Charleston — that being considered the weakest point.
The iron clad frigate Lonsides, the Monitor battery Montaux, and the Monitor battery Passaic, had all arrived at Port Royal.
The transport ship Sparkling Sea, of the Banks expedition, has proved a total loss.
She had on heard the 25th New York battery, all the horses of which were drowned.
The men were at Key West on the 20th having lost all their appliances for active service.
It is rumored at Washington that McClellan has resigned, and that Major-Gen. Porter has been arrested for improper conduct.

Banks has sent an urgent request to Hunter, at Port Royal, for all the entrenching tools he can possibly spare.
The Times infers from this that the capture of Port Hudson, of which it had been anxiously expecting to hear, is a long way in the future.
Gold went up in New York Tuesday to 154½@155, but at the afternoon board fell back to 153½@153⅝. Exchange on London jumped to 163@170,

div4.head: Foreign News.
div4.p:
The Saxonia has reached New York, with advices from Europe to the 14th.
The most important feature of the news is the address of the French Emperor at the opening of the Corps Legislatif, which is thought to shadow forth French intervention in the affairs of the United States.
He said:

q.p: "I have made the attempt to send beyond the Atlantic advices inspired by a sincere sympathy; but the great Powers not having thought it advisable as yet to act in concert with me, have been obliged to postpone to a mere suitable opportunity the offer of mediation the object of which was to stop the effusion of blood, and to prevent the exhaustion of a country the future of which cannot be looked upon with indifference."

div4.p: The Times's Paris correspondent says, "the impression produced in the better class of the French population by the Emperor's discourse is unfavorable to the United States,"

The Minister of Foreign Affairs, in his official report of the policy of the Empire with reference to America, says that the Imperial Government had not neglected any opportunity which authorized it to explain its opinion to the Federal Government on the dangers and difficulties of the situation.
The Emperor has taken care to inform the Government at Washington that he is quite ready, if it should be desired, to facilitate either alone or collectively, in any form that might be indicated, the work of peace.

div3.head: Latest from the North.
div3.p:
The New York Tribune, of the 29th, has a few items of importance.
We glean the following from its columns:

q.p:
General Joseph E. Johnston commands the rebel department of the West.
He is able to concentrate 150,000 men.

div3.p: The rebels are determined to stake everything to hold Vicksburg and Port Hudson, and keep open communication between Louisiana, Arkansas, and Texas.

Burnside, on Tuesday last, tendered the President his resignation as an officer of the U. S. Army.
Lincoln, however, declined to receive it, and informed Burnside that he had "other fish for him to fry." Burnside acquiesced, and announced his readiness to accept even the smallest command.

Gen. Franklin, in his farewell address to his corps, says: "In severing the connection which you have made so dear, I ask that no one will believe that I willingly part with you in the face of the enemy"

In the U. S. Senate on Tuesday, Mr. Saulabury, of Delaware, made a speech, in which he denounced Lincoln as an "imbecile." The Vice-President called him to order several times, and finally ordered the Sergeant-at-Arms to take him into custody.
Saulabury displayed a revolver and went out. The next day Mr. Clark, of New Hampshire, offered a resolution for his expulsion, which lies over.

The Tribune's correspondent says that the "Ze cash" Senator from Delaware seemed phrenzied with rage, and was observed flourishing a challenge to the mover, who, doubtless, would decline the "invitation," He also threatened to take the life of John W. Forney, the Secretary of the Senate for remarks made in the Chronicle.
The editor of the Philadelphia Evening Journal has been arrested as a Secession sympathizer.
The Baltimore American, of the 29th, states that the rebel steamer Florida Capt. Semmes, captured and destroyed seven Northern vessels off the West India Islands.

The Confederate States steamer Oreta has arrived at Havana for coal.
She had destroyed several Yankee vessels.
A Washington correspondent alleges that Butler is the popular choice for the office of Secretary of War.
Wendell Phillips, and other strong-minded men of his stamp, went in a body on Monday night to the President's house, and demanded the removal of Seward.
Mr. Wall, of New Jersey, introduced a resolution for extending relief to and inquiring into the case of, Col, Zarvana; which was adopted.
The latest quotations of gold are $1.53. Exchange $1.66½. Cotton 60 cents.

div3.head: Linen Wrapping paper.
div3.p:
--Our conductor told us a curious circumstance about the ornamental papers which wrap round the "pieces" of linen. "We are obliged," said he, "to have different styles for different nations of customers.
Now, it might make all the odds of sale or not sale to a Yankee whether the wrapper were a gay or a dull color, Consequently, we send very flash patterns to America always, while soberer ones 'take' in England.
The Spanish market likes bright colors also; scarlets and yellows particularly.
Blues do better in France — blue and silver, or some pretty contrast of the kind." We learn also that a very large sum yearly is paid away from Ireland by the manufacturers, mainly to French designers for these very papers, and for the ornamented boxes in which sets of cambric handkerchiefs are packed.
Some of these latter have prints on their which, for accuracy of outline and purify of coloring, are worthy of a better place, and the marvel is, by what minuteness or remuneration to the artist and workmen these can be given gratis with the goods.
Irish Schools of Art ought surely to be able to meet the demands for tasteful and trained designers now.--Leisures Hour.

div4.p: --The Senate met at 12 o'clock M., and was called to order by the Lieut. Governor Prayer by Rev. Dr. Edwards.

A communication from the House announced their disagreement to the 1st and 2d sections of the act entitled "An act to discharge from actual service persons who have furnished substitutes," and their agreement to the 3d; and, after considerable discussion, the Senate refused to recede from their amendment, and the House was notified thereof.
A communication from the Sergeant-at-Arms, resigning his position, was received, read, and laid upon the table.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--By Mr. Nashs That the Committee on Extortion, take into consideration the propriety of waiting upon the Secretary of War in regard to the transportation of private freight over the railroads of the Commonwealth.
By Mr. Neeson: On imposing civil disabilities on traitorous; citizens, aiding the enemy.
By Mr. Marshall; On refunding to the Sheriff of Fauquier county a certain sum of money therein named.
By Mr. Christian, of Angusta.
On amending the law authorizing free negroes to he sold into slavery, so as to require the clerks of Courts to report the purchase money to the Auditor, as a charge against the Sheriff an receiving it. By Mr. Cogbill: On refunding to Powhatan Jones and others a certain sum of money.
By Mr. Robertson Whether day, and, if any, what, legislation is necessary in regard to a large tract of land owned by alien enemies of the State of Virginia, also, to make it the duty of Commissioners of the revenue to take lists of all the goods and chattels of non-residents.
By Mr. Greever.
On instructing the Committee on Roads and Internal Improvements to inquire into the expediency of incorporating a joint stock company to improve the North fork of the Holston river, in Smyth county, etc.
An act for the relief of the securities of the Sheriff of Appomattox was passed.

A communication was read from the Executive, accompanied by voluminous documents, vindicating himself from the charges brought against him in the Confederate House of Representatives, of a disposition to throw obstacles in the way of Congressional comfort.
etc., was laid upon the table.
On motion of Mr. Johnson, at 2½ o'clock P. M., the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows.
The Committee on Courts reported a bill legalizing the acts of the County Court of Spotsylvania county, held during the year 1862 at other places than at the court-house of said county.
The House concurred in the Senate's amendments to the bill in relation to fencing, &c., in certain counties.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--The following resolutions of inquiry were submitted: By Mr. Noland, into the expediency of providing by law for the payment of interest on the war tax bonds to those banks which have been prevented, by the presence of the enemy, from demanding the same at the time and in the manner required by law; by Mr. Burks, into the expediency of amending the Code of Virginia relative to allowing slaves to go at large and hire themselves out; by Mr. Shannor; into the expediency of incorporating a joint stock company for the improvement of the North fork of the Holson river, in Smyth county.
Mr. Noland submitted the following letter from Dr. Gibson, which he asked to have read:

div5.opener:
Richmond, Jan. 31, 1863. Major B. P. Noland, House of Delegates:
Dear Sir.
div5.p: --I find in the papers this morning that Mr. Mallory, of Brunswick, and Mr. J. T. Anderson, of Botetourt, stated yesterday in the House of Delegates that they had been informed I was receiving a salary of $25,000 per annum for my services as Surgeon General of Virginia, and with nothing to do.

Not supposing that these gentlemen designed to impeach my character, but that they simply wish to correct abuses, I appeal not to them but to you, as a member of the House, personally known to me, to make the following statement to the honorable body before whom that statement was made:

During the session of the Convention of the State in April, 1861, I was appointed by that body Surgeon General of Virginia, and performed the duties of the office until the arrival of the Confederate Government at Richmond — a period of about forty days. Soon afterwards I was appointed a Surgeon in the Confederate Army, and from that hour my pay as Surgeon General of Virginia ceased I drew form the State of Virginia pay for forty days--as well as my memory serves me, at the rate of $3,000 per annum, viz: about $330.

There were for some months duties to be discharged, pertaining to the office of Surgeon General, which were performed by me without pay or expectation of pay. During the forty days, the Governor, the Executive Council, and nearly two hundred medical officers, appointed by them on my nomination, can testify that the office was not a sine cure.
Will you have the goodness to have this letter read to the House to day, as I am anxious to have any impressions which to-day's paper may make on persons not cognizant of the facts at once erased.

Mr. Mallory stated that in his remarks of the previous day he had preferred no charges against Dr. Gibson.
He had received the statement from a source entitled to credit, and thought it a subject which the interest of the Treasury, as well as of Dr. G. himself, demanded investigation.
He was glad to learn, through the letter just read, that the rumor was unfounded.

Mr. Anderson also disavowed any intention to do injustice to Dr. Gibson.
He had no knowledge of the matter beyond what he had stated yesterday, in reply to the gentleman from Brunswick.
On motion of Mr. Marye, the bill just reported, legalizing the acts of the County Court of Spotsylvania, was taken up, read a second time, and ordered to its engrossment.

At 12½ o'clock the Speaker announced that the hour had arrived for the consideration of the order of the day — the bill for the suppression of extortion — when Mr. Hunter, being entitled to the floor, resumed his argument begun on yesterday, in opposition to the bill.
He was interrupted during the progress of his remarks by a massage from the Senate, announcing to the House the refusal of that body to recede from its amendments to the bill exempting from military service those persons who have furnished substitutes for the war.

Mr. Lynn followed Mr. Hunter, in behalf of the bill.
At the conclusion of his remarks.
Mr. Forbes offered a resolution declaring that all debate on the subject then before the House shall cease at 1½ o'clock on Monday.
The motion was received with manifest disapprobation by the House, and it was withdrawn by the mover; whereupon.
Mr. Robinson, of Richmond city, moved an adjournment until 12 o'clock Monday, which was carried.

div3.head: Paroled Yankee Wanderers.
div3.p:
The Augusta (Ga.) Constitutionalist says, that two Yankee deserters passed through that city last week on their way further South.
They had the proper passports from the Richmond authorities, and were going to obtain employment at some other point.
It appears to us that it is rather dangerous to allow these deserters to spread themselves through the Confederacy, as spies or other dangerous characters might smuggle themselves into the country under this pretext.

The Lynchburg (Virginia) Republican says a number of Yankee prisoners and deserters, who have taken the oath at Richmond, are now at work at some iron furnaces in Rockbridge county, and it is informed that--

Some of these Abolitionists, oblivious of the obligation of allegiance scarcely cold upon their lips, are tampering with slaves, committing numberless robberies, and leaving the works with the openly avowed design of making their way back to the North.
The policy of receiving these men as citizens is to say the least, questionable, for we hold that a Yankee who foreswears his own section will never be true to our's. Personal interest is by far the majority of cases of those who have taken the oath since the war commenced has been the motive principle with them, and the desire to get their carcasses out of the Yankee army and thus out of the reach of Southern bullets and can non balls.
We have no faith in a Yankee's oath whateve.
Whenever it suits him he will perjure himself, and turn and sting the people from whom he has received favor.
Those of them who have come over to us since the war are of the most contemptible class.
with not an idea above roguery and villainy, and it is impossible to make honest men of them.
They need watching and our people should be on their guard against them.
We have reason to believe that some of the two hundred who took the oath several weeks since in Richmond, are now prowling in this region.
We were called upon yesterday by one of them, who answered an advertisement for an overseer in this paper, who had the unblushing effrontery to offer himself for the place.
With supreme impertinence he announced himself from "York State," meaning New York, and was fortified by a certificate from Thomas P. Turner, commander of the prisons in Richmond, that he had a few weeks since taken the oath.
We questioned him, and were informed that he was "drafted" into the Yankee army, and was discharged therefrom at Harrison's Landing last summer, after McClellan's reverses before Richmond, and had since run the blockade and come South.
The drafting part of this statement in notoriously untrue, for the reason that there was no draft in the North until after the battle before Richmond; and having detected him in a falsehood once, we took his whole statement as false, as far as it bore upon anything favorable to the South.
More than likely the certificate was a forged one, and the fallow may have made his escape from some one of our prisons.
What safety is there for us, when such cattle as these are allowed to prowl at will over the country?
Our slaves will be tampered with and run off, railroad bridges.
mysteriously burnt and other escape depredations committed by them.
They will in our candid opinion, only remain long enough to accomplish their evil designs, to say out and obtain information, and then — over the hills and far away," to their own country.
So bare in the Lincoln Government that this oath-taking business may be but a part of a systematic plan to injure the South and obtain information, fostered had encouraged by it and if our Government will turn the ravels loose upon us our people should that they do no harm.
We warn them in time of the danger, and we invoke them to be watchful.
If they value their own safety, they should sooner receive into their houses the most venomous reptile that crawis the earth than one of there newly converted Yankees.
They are wolves in sheep's clothing, and time and experience (which has already shown to us their deep and malignant ) will but serve to show the necessity of our playing words-- "Beware of them."

div3.head: The New attack on Vicksburg.
div3.p:
The Vicksburg Whig. of the 23d says the cranes of last July are about to be renewed.
The day before exactly resembled the morning of the 15th of that month.
It says:

q.p:
All day transports were bringing down troops and landing them about a mile and a half above the famous canal.
Camp fires were visible along the levee, and large squads of the enemy could be observed with a glass about the canal.
In the afternoon, White's floyd was dotted with trade and troops were recognize the river in front of Dr. Young's (the old Stone) place.
Some twenty transports were fastened to the Louisiana bank, and one was on guard on the Mississippi shore, just opposite White's cotton gin. Among the transports that came down with troops during the day, we noticed the following; Platic Valley, Lioness, Kannett, Von Phul Continental Gen. Anderson, Silver Moon, Hlawatha, and Emmr, An iron-clad gunboat came down about noon and took up its position below the transports.
Occasional visitors, in the shape of shells, were sent over to the troops who were pitching their tents, by our men at the lower batteries, but the effect is not known.
They are, we believe out of range of any of our guns.
The mortar below the city commenced bellowing slowly is the afternoon and a few shots were fired from the upper batteries during the day. The enemy appear to be concentrating a large force near their old camp ground; but our mortar, if fired at intervals, will render their situation very unpleasant.
It would seem that they have given up the Yazoo for the present, at least, and will attempt the reduction of Vicksburg by a new route.

div3.p: A letter from Vicksburg to the Mobile Advertiser dated the 23d, says:

q.p:
The enemy has again approached to the vicinity of the famous Yankee canal, and a large force was yesterday engaged in reconnoitering that work.--The river is now rising rapidly, and in a few days the water will run through the ditch.
The plan is to run some of his barges through, by which means he will be able to throw his troops across the river below, and perhaps, on some dark night he may attempt to run some of the iron-clads by our batteries, and then he will be able to bring his troops over the river below under the protection of his gunboats.
Whatever may be his plans, it is certain that the taking of Vicksburg is a terribly hard job, and he will find it so before he gets through.
The guns from our batteries commanding the river are all engaged in practicing, and finding their range and effect.
Several shots have been aimed at the Yankee gunboats, but, they are yet too far in the distance.

div3.p: The communication on the Vicksburg and Shreveport railroad has been interrupted, and several persons coming through on that road yesterday were captured by the Yankees. Gen. Lee was this morning engaged in inspecting the works about the city, and everything that can add to their strength will be immediately attended to.

div3.head: The Manufacture of Confederate money at the North.
div3.p:
--In Morgan's late raid into Kentucky a man named Geo. Barber was captured, with the correspondence given below on his person.
It is needless to add that Barber was "lost in the woods" after being taken:

div4.opener:
Elizabethtown, Ky., Nov. 16th, 1863. Messrs R. Jones & Co.:
Sirs:
div4.p:
I say your advertisement, which I enclose I would like to purchase of you some of the Confederate money you have.
If it is of the kind I want --bills with a written signature on them — I will buy some $1,000 of it, as I can use it soon.
Please send me a sample by return until and oblige yours, truly,
On the blank about attached to the above, the following answer is written:

div5.p:
Enclosed we send you samples of bills we have.
Those with the red numbers are exact and perfect imitations of Confederate fives.
We also have perfect counterfeits of the $20 bills.
They are the only perfect counterfeits or fac similes yet issued.
They are exact imitations, in paper, engraving and every other way. Compare them with the genuine and criticise them no much as you please.
They have been gotten up at a great expense.
The steel plates for those bills coat over $1,000 a piece.
We have sold large quantities to cotton dealers and persons going South in the last two or three weeks.--The bills have only been on sale a few weeks.
It will be some weeks before the $40, $50, and $100 plates are ready for the press.
We sell those bills at $10 per 100 bills, or $90 per 1,000, sent postage paid or by express, which is, you are aware, only nine or ten cents each.
The common wood out bills, of which we also send specimens, we sell at $4 per 100 bills, or $35 per 1,000 bills.
All orders from you will receive prompt attention — privately.
div5.closer:
Yours, truly,
K. Jones & Co., Box 1261.

div5.p:
P. S.--'We do not sell less than 100 bills of the best quality, and thus far have said them faster than we could print them.
Should thou purchase we can leave the numbers on the bills blank.

div3.head: Torpedo warfare.
div3.p:
The invention of means for the submarine use of powder is one of the legacies left America by Robert Fulton, and although deprecatory and opprobious arguments have for a long time been used against this mode of warfare by Governments whose geographical peculiarities and situation in regard to other maritime powers rendered it necessary to maintain immense fleets, we think it will yet become a tremendous weapon, and one that will enable any country to stand on the defence without the necessity of a regular army at every port and channel fortification at a cost of millions upon millions of dollars.
Although as yet it has failed to secure a favorable ear from many military men, its importance in countries whose domestic institutions and prosperity forbid the maintenance of large armies and navies, will become so apparent as to secure its adoption.
Military men are, of course rare inventors, and not generally the first to adopt inventions.
Besides this, torpedo warfare may appear to diminish the importance of their profession as a calling, which, to some extent, perhaps have dissuaded military men from recommending its adoption.

But, like gunpowder, it will finally be adopted into the legitimate resources of military warfare, and although it may never be perfected to such an extent as to warrent our relying mainly on it for the defence of our harbors, it will prove a very valuable adjunct for the defence of ports from the over whelming iron-clad fleets of an enemy.
Mr. Fulton himself investigated and ascertained the effect of submarine explosions to convince the skepties, Lord Mellville, Pitt, Livingston, and others.
His first experiment was on a Danish brig.
anchored near Deal, in October, 1805. One hundred and eighty pounds of powder were placed in a torpedo, which the tide carried under the brig. In eighteen minutes [the torpedo worked by a clock inside] an explosion took place which raised the vessel bodily out of the water.
She separated in the middle, and the two ends went down.
The pumps and foremast were blown out of her, missen mast broke in two places, force chain plates and bolts torn out and the fore top yard thrown to the cross trees.-- The next experiment was made in New York harbor, in 1809, where two thousand persons witnessed the explosion of a brig much after the style of the Danish vessel just described. --An attempt was made at Norfolk, in 1813, to destroy the British frigate Plantages, lying in the harbor, and would have proved perfectly successful, but the clock-work was set to too short an interval.
As it was, however, it made the English very cautious in future movements, and put a stop to their barbarities along the coast.
As the torpedo neared the vessel it exploded in the most awful manner, throwing up an immense column of water, which fell upon her desk, and opposing a yawning gulf into which she appeared to have rapidly drifted.
Her forecastle had been turn off and the crew took to their boats, perfectly panic stricken.
Fulton's "swivel harpeon" method of attaching and exploding torpedoes was used by the British in 1805, when they attacked a couple of French gun-brigs lying in Boulogua roads, but they failed to destroy the boats, though they were violently shaken.
The trifling causes which prevented their destruction were ascertained by Mr. Fulton, who avoided them in future experiments.
Chambers, in his history of the Russian war, says that two British vessels were injured by coming in contact with sunken torpedoes.--They were scattered closely along near the fortress of Cronstrads, and would have proved very disastrous had the fleet attempted to force a passage.
The blowing up of the ship Cyballa at Berry Island, in the Bahamas, where the stern post was entirely detached from the frame, might also be cited to prove the practicability of torpedoes, but we have enumerated enough for our purpose.
The latest and best proof we have was the destruction of the heavy iron-clad gunboat Cairo on the Yazoo river a few weeks ago. That settles the question beyond a doubt, and if our Government will take the matter in hand and select proper men to take charge of the "torpedo warfare," and conduct it on an extensive scale, the Abolitionists will be without a gunboat on the lower Mississippi or a man of war in front of any of our ports, in less than three months.--Vicksburg Whig.

argument.p: the blockaders at Charleston driven off.--two sunk and one set on fire — not a man lost by the Confederate--the blockade declared — to be raised — action of the Foreign Consuls — the blockaders Reappear, &c., &c.

div4.p:
--The two iron-clad gunboats Chicora and Palmetto Stale; with three steamers as tenders, went out beyond the bar at 1 o'clock this morning to attack the blockading fleet.
Firing began soon after one, and for a time was very rapid and continuous.

Afterwards it slackened, but continued at intervals until 9 o'clock this morning.
Owing to the , the result has not yet been ascertained.
Commander Ingraham is aboard the Palmetto State, as commander of the expedition.

div4.head: [second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--This morning the gunboats Palmetto State, Captain Nutledge, and Chicora, Capt. Tucker, accompanied by three small steamers, the Gen.
Clinch, Etiwan, and Chester field, all under the command of Commoders — Ingraham made an attack on the blockaders, and succeeded in sinking two and crippling a third.
The engagement commenced at 4 o'clock. The Palmetto State, with Commodore Ingraham on board, opened fire upon the Federal gunboat Hercedita carrying 11 guns and 153 men, which was soon sunk in five fathoms water.

Her commander, Captain Stettwagon, with a boat's crow, came on board and surrendered.
One shot pierced her boiler, going clear through.
Capt. Stettwagon and crew were paroled by Commodors Ingraham.

Captain Tucker, of the Chicora, reports sinking another Federal gunboat, and the disabling of the steamship Quaker City.
The latter was set on fire by the Chicora and hauled down her flag to surrender, but afterwards managed to escape, using only one wheel.
She was very seriously damaged.
The number of the blockading fleet outside at the time of the attack was thirteen, with two first class frigates, the Susquehanna and Canandaigua.
The Federal loss is very severe.

It was a complete success on our part, with not a man hurt.
Our gunboats were not even struck.
All the blockaders have disappeared.
There is not one to be seen within five miles with the strongest kind of glasses.
Our boats are now returning to Charleston.
The following is the official dispatch:

div5.p: "On Board Gunboat Palmetto State.

"I went out last night.
This vessel struck the Merzedita, when she sent a boat on board and surrendered.
The officers and crew were paroled. --Captain Tucker thinks he sunk one vessel and set another on fire, when the struck her flag.
The blockading fleet had gone to southward and eastward, out of sight.
Ninety-four prisoners, including three negroes, from the Yankee gunboat John P. Smith, arrived here this morning.

div4.head: [third Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--Our gunboats Palmetto State and Chicago have reached the wharves — They were enthusiastically cheered by an immense concourse of citizens, who had assembled to greet them.
Salutes were fired from all the forts and batteries.
Not a man was hurt on our side and our gunboats were not struck by the enemy.
Our attack on the fleet was a complete surprise to the blockaders, each one running away without earing for the others.
It is supposed that nearly all of the crew of the Mersadita perished, the Palmetto State (which engaged her) having no boats and fighting at the time, could render her ance. The Quaker City was struck twice, and one of her side wheels almost torn off.
The Federal gunboat John P. Smith, captured on the Stono yesterday, had 8 killed and 15 wounded. Her Chief Engineer, Turner, was killed.

A Yankee gunboat came to the month of Stono river this afternoon and fired five shots, but soon retired.
She did not damage, and no one was hurt on our side.

div4.head: [Fourth Dispatch.]
div4.p: --General Beauregard and Commodore Ingraham, as commanders of the land and naval forces, have issued a joint proclamation, dated Jan'y 31, declaring the blockade of Charleston raised — the entire hostile squadron having been sunk, burned, or dispersed, by the superior naval forces of the Confederacy.

Yesterday afternoon Gen. Beauregard placed a steamer at the disposal of the foreign Consuls to see for themselves that no blockade existed.
The French and Spanish Consuls, accompanied by Gen. Ripley, accepted the invitation.
The British Consul, with the commander of the British war steamer Petrel, had previously gone five miles beyond the usual anchorage of the blockader, and could see nothing of them with glasses.
Late in the evening four blockaders reappeared, keeping far out. This evening a large number of blockaders are in sight, but keep steam up, evidently ready to run.
Lieut. Sheldon and Chief Engineer Prinble, of the Yankee gunboat Flambeau, were captured by our scouts on Ball's Island last night.

div5.head:
Official proclamation.
Headq's land and naval forces,
Charleston, S C. Jan. 31, 1863.
div5.p: At about 5 o'clock this morning the Confederate States naval forces in this station attacked the U. S. blockading fleet off the harbor of the city of Charleston, and sunk, dispersed, or drove off and out of sight for the time, the entire hostile fleet; therefore we, the undersigned, commanders, respectively, of the Confederate States naval and land forces in this quarter, do hereby formally declare the blockade by the United States of the said city of Charleston, S. C., to be raised by a superior force of the Confederate States from and after this 31st day of January, A. D. 1863.
div5.closer:
(Signed) G. T. Beauregard,
General Commanding.
D. N. Ingraham,
Flag Officer Com'g Naval Forces in S. C. Official:
Thomas Jourdan, Chief of Staff.

div5.p: The results of the naval engagements yesterday are, two vessels sunk, four set on fire, and the remainder driven away.
The foreign Consuls here held a meeting last night, and were unanimously of opinion that the blockade had been legally raised.
Twenty blockaders are off the bar to-day.

The gunboat John P. Smith, captured from the Federals in Stone river, is now safely anchored under the guns of Fort Pemberton.
She has one Parrot gun, ten 8-inch guns, and one 34-pounder. --She will soon be ready for sea.
Two prisoners, captured while on a gunning expedition on Bull's Island, were brought in to-day. --They belong to the steamer Flambeau, blockading the port of Georgetown.

div3.head: Capture of a Yankee gunboat in the Stone river, near Charleston.
div3.p:
--Several days ago General Ripley dispatched a force for artillery, commanded by Lieut.-Col. Yates, to James Island, with the design of attacking the Yankee gunboats cruising in Stone river.
About eight miles from the city Lieut.-Col. Yates posted his guns, twenty-one in number, in a simi-circle, stretching on both sides of the river around the gunboat John P. Smith, and at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon opened a concentrated fire upon her. She replied with broadsides.

The engagement lasted one hour, when the gunboat hauled down her flag, surrendering unconditionally,with one hundred and eighty prisoners. She carried eleven guns.
Many of the crew were killed and wounded.
Our loss only one man wounded.
Other very important movements are in progress here.

div3.head: From Vicksburg.
div3.p:
--The Advertiser and Register has a dispatch, dated Vicksburg, 33th inst., which says scouting parties appeared this morning on the river bank opposite Vicksburg, and burned four houses under the range of our batteries.
They are supposed to be creating batteries opposite the town.
There are no new movements among the fleet.

div3.head: The fight near Suffolk.
div3.p:
--The enemy attacked Gen. Pryer's command about 4 o'clock Friday morning at Kelly's, in Nousemond county, eight miles from Suffolk.
The fight lasted four home.
The enemy was repulsed at every point.
Gen. Pryor's official dispatches say that our loss in killed and wounded was less than fifty.
The enemy is reported to have suffered severely.
Among the killed is Col. Poage, of Pulaski, 4th Va., and Capt. Dubbies, of Floyd county, 27th Va. battalion.
The news from Charleston created great joy here.

div3.head: Five transports destroyed by Wheeler's Horse Marince.
div3.p:
-- General Wheeler's cavalry attacked a fleet of twenty-five Federal transports on the Cumberland river, and destroyed five, on last Friday.
The fleet was accompanied by two gunboats.
On coming down from Nashville, on Saturday, Wheeler's cavalry destroyed a locomotive and five cars at Lavergue, and captured the guard of fifty-two men.
The vigorous movements of our cavalry have evidently disconcerted all the plans of Rosecrans.

div3.head: Another Unsuccessful bombardment of Fort McAllister.
div3.p:
--The Abolition fleet, consisting of one iron-clad turret, four gunboats, and one mortar boat, again attacked Fort McAllister, at Generals Point, this morning.
The firing continued until 2½ this afternoon, when the enemy retired, whipped again.
The bombardment was more furious than the last.
The only person killed on our side was Major John B. Gallic, commander of the fort, a shell striking him in the head.

div3.head: Brutal attempt to murder.
div3.p:
--A most brutal attempt to murder Mr. A. R. Pitts, the manager on the plantation of Messrs P. H & W. R. Aylett in the county of King William, was made on Friday night last by a negro named Richard.
Mr. Pitts left his house for a few moments to reprimand the negro in question for not obeying his order, and as he did not return as soon as he was expected.
Mrs. Pitts left the house to look for him. She found her husband lying senseless in the yard with his head horribly mangled, and the unfortunate gentleman unable to speak.
Physicians were at once sent for, and although every care has been bestowed upon him, but little hope is entertained of his recovery.
Mr. Pitts was the manager at "Malvern Hill" when the great battle was fought at that place.
A reward is advertised in this paper for the arrest of the assassin.

div3.head: Prison items.
div3.p: --The following parties were lodged in Castle Thunder on Saturday and Sunday: R Morgan co H. 4th N. C, desertion; Alex O'neal, alias Jas Ryan, supposed deserter; S Mitchell, co B, 38th N. C. desertion; Chas Eaton, suspicious character, supposed substitute; Jno Graham, do, and supposed deserter; Mary Robinson, free negroes, by order of Gen. Winder; Pat Cane, drunk and disorderly; Thos Cane, do; Robert Thomasson, selling liquor; Thos. Higgins, do; Seth N. Hollister, Yankee deserter; Pat Caffrey, co D, 5th Ala. battalion, desertion; John Sinclair and Anthony Smalley, do. Preparations were made yesterday to send 150 men from Castle Thunder to the army.

div3.head: Robbed.
div3.p: --A negro man was accosted yesterday morning at the corner of 25th and Main streets, by a lot of youthful ragmuffins, who surrounded him and while some were pretending to sell him a set of studs one of them seized his pocket-back, when the whole party ran off, leaving Coffee disconsolate.

div3.head: Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--On Saturday the following Abolition prisoners were brought to Richmond and lodged in the Libby prison: Alfred Winder, telegraphic operator; and Privates Wm Wilson, co H, 3d Va; J. D. Jackson, co B. P. Glover, co H. and Jacob Curder, co B. of the same regiment — all of whom were captured at Braxton county.
Va.

div3.head: Marriage. Licenses.
div3.p:
--The Clerk of Richmond Hustings Court during the month of January issued 34 marriage licenses — a considerable increase on the previous month.
The war and high price of provisions has had no effect in lessening the number of marriages, which have rather increased.

div3.head: A prisoner.
div3.p: --John J. Thomas, a Union member of the Maryland Legislature, who was taken in custody by Gen. Stuart in his raid in Maryland, is now a prisoner in Castle Booker, in this city.

div3.head: Present to the soldiers.
div3.p: --The Governor of Virginia has received from a patriotic lady, of this city, an elegant set of Russia sable furs, to be sold for the benefit of the soldiers of Virginia.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p: -- In the absence of the Mayor to-day, Recorder James K. Cassin presided.

Daniel Logan, alias Gustavus Taylor, was arraigned for stealing a $2 Confederate note, and a box of cigars, worth $17, from William Kenack.--The proof sustaining the allegation, the defendant was sent on to await the action of the Grand Jury of the Hustings Court at its February term and balled in the sum of $300 for his appearance --John W. McDowell becoming his surety.

Benjamin W Carter and Thomas Samanni, two young white men, were arraigned for forging the name of Juan Pisstul to a check for $180, payable at the Exchange Bank of Virginia.
The alleged offence was committed on Friday.
They were remanded to the 4th of February for further examination.

William R. Warden was arraigned on sundry charges.
First for feloniously obtaining, on the 30th of January, by false pretences, from Richard Southern, two hogsheads of sugar, worth $1,916.--The case was continued until the 3d of February. Secondly, Warden was charged with obtaining, by the same means on the 29th of January, 10 boxes of candles, worth $440, from Antonis Cozalioni — The charge was dismissed.
Thirdly, Warden was charged with having obtained, by the same means above alluded to 8 kegs of lard worth $700 from John C. Taylor.
In this case the Recorder committed him for further examination before the next Hustings Court, which will convene on the second Monday in February.

Habeas Corpus --Thomas Martin, a member of the Letcher Artillery, Captain Greenlee Davidson, on Saturday, applied to Judge Lyons, of the Hustings Court, for a writ of habeas corpus, in which he claims that he is illegally head as a soldier.
The question will be argued before Judge Lyons the present week.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 28, page 2.

div3.head: The Rupture of the blockade of Charleston.
div3.p:
The blockade of Charleston has been broken — the Secretary of State has given notice of the fact to the British and French Consuls — by the strict rule of international law, the Yankees must give sixty days notice before they can re-establish it. The question is whether or not the Yankees will be bound by that law, seeing that they affect to regard us as rebels, and therefore not entitled to the benefits of international law, and whether or not Lord Russell will allow their claim of right to exclude us from such benefit.
We have no doubt that the Yankees will make the claim, and that Russell will submit to it. The whole conduct of the man, during this war, leads us to this conclusion.

In the beginning, it was tained by the London Times, and no doubt by the English Ministry, that no nation had a right to blockade its own ports, and that if the Yankees insisted on blockading the Confederate ports, they must acknowledge them as no longer . In other words, the blockade of our ports was insisted to be an acknowledgment of our separate existence.
This was soon given up by Russell, if, indeed, he ever insisted upon it in Parliament, which we believe he did, though we are not certain.
Nor was it all that he gave up. By the treaty of Paris in 1856, it was decided that a blockade to be respected must be efficient. When called on to explain what would be considered an efficient blockade, the Palmerston Ministry established the rule that the entrance and departure of five ships into and from a blockaded port was evidence that the blockade was not efficient.
Now, instead of five, five hundred vessels have entered and left the port of Charleston since it was declared to be blockaded.
Yet, the complaisant British Minister, for Foreign Affairs still regards the blockade of Charleston as effective.-- If, there are, the Yankees restore the blockade without notice, we have no doubt that he will look with perfect nonchalance upon the capture of any number of British ships that may attempt to enter.
He is quite too polite to give offence to the Yankee Adams.

Besides the glory of the deed, therefore, and the opportunity which the dispersion of the Yankee ships affords to merchant vessels to enter the port — and these considerations are of great moment — we do not see that any permanent advantage into be derived.
We have no idea that Lord Russell would take it in dungeon were the Yankees to capture any number of English ships without notice.
We must keep our ports open by the strong hand.
Our seamen will do it if they are only permitted.

div3.head: Wheeler Destroys more transports.
div3.p:
Wheeler, with his "horse marines," has again pitched into the enemy's transports on the Cumberland river, and destroyed five of them, with a good deal of valuable stores.
This new feature of the war — the triumphs of cavalry on the water --is conferring as much pleasure upon the people of the South as it is favor upon Gen. Wheeler.
Men begin to suspect that he fights with iron-clad horses!
He is giving the enemy a deal of trouble.

div3.head: The Confederate Navy.
div3.p:
Since the days of Paul Jones there have been no achievements of a single ship in naval warfare as brilliant as those of the Alabama.
Capt. Semmas has won for himself and his country imperishable laurels.
The Florida, which has just put to sea under her gallant commander, bids fair to rival the renown of the Alabama.
The Navy Department and the Confederate Congress ought to devote their utmost energies to putting more ships afloat, and giving an opportunity to our gallant naval offices to distinguish themselves and render service to the Confederacy.
The is the only arena upon which we can carry on aggressive warfare against the Yankees, and touch them in the vital spot of both their pride and interests.
The extreme sensitiveness manifested in their commercial circles to the operations of a single ship, the Alabama shown us their weak spot, and we should strike at it with all our power.
With all the boasted prowess of the Yankee upon the deep, we believe that a Confederate navy can be built up which will make the sea as uncomfortable to them as the shore, and drive their commerce — the source of all their wealth — from the face of the

div3.head: Is he a man or a dog?
div3.p: A Northern paper informs us that the President of the Yankees, after reading some severe strictures upon his character in one of the newspapers exclaimed, "Am I Abraham Lincoln, or am I a dog?"

We trust that the natural philosophers of Doodledom will make haste to assist their master in the solution of this open question.
It is one which involves not only his own status, but the classification of the entire race of which he is the representative dog, or man, as the case may be — They have deliberately elected as their Chief Magistrate a nondescript, who is himself unable to decide whether he is a man or a dog. Posterity, judging them by their actions, will never believe that either Abraham or his followers were men.--But it does not follow, because they are not entitled to the name of men that they are dogs.--We should be loath to do such injustice to "those American citizens" of canine descent whom Nature has denied the means of defending themselves from the imputation implied in the inquiry, "Am I Abraham Lincoln, or am I a dog?" Abraham is certainly not a dog — at all events, not a dog of the higher classes.
He is no dog of St. Bernard or Newfoundland, for his instincts are destructive not conservative, and his manners lack the majestic dignity and repose of those benevolent and magnanimous creatures.
He is not a bulldog nor a mastiff; for while he is more ferocious than either, he is neither honest nor brave.
He is not a shepherd's dog, for he worries and scatters instead of guiding and guarding the sheep.
He has gone of the vulgar habits of dogs and like the dog in the fable, he jumps into the stream after the shadow of meat, and loses the substance.
But the good sense and affectionateness of even the lowest order of ours are beyond the capacity of the Yankee President.
On the whole, we should be inclined to answer the question. "Am I Abraham Lincoln or am I a dog?"--you are Abraham Lincoln.

Among the victims of the present war we have to number Lieut. Col. St. George Tucker, who died on Saturday week in Charlottesville.
He was formerly Clerk of the House of Delegates.
He was amongst the earliest in the war, and served with honor in the Peninsula, where he contracted the disease which terminated after some months in his death.
Gentleman, scholar, soldier, and Christian, he goes to his untimely grave amongst the noblest, most generous and gallant of all the brave young men who have fallen a sacrifice for the liberty and independence of the South.

div3.head: Attack on tories in East Tennessee.
div3.p:
--A band of tories, about seventy in number, under an outlaw named Taylor, were attacked on the 23d, in Johnson county, Tenn., by forty of our men, under Col. Folk.
A letter says:

q.p:
The tory cavalry and infantry were parading in a field near the Springs.
Col. Folk ordered his men to swim, the river and charge them.
The tories seeing this, abandoned their horses and took shelter upon the summit of a large ridge.
Folk's men were then dismounted, and charged up the ridge, completely dispersing the tories.
All of their horses were captured.
Four of the tories were killed, and a number wounded and captured.
The captured were immediately hung, by order of Col. Folk.
Taylor was killed.

div3.head: Piety in a General.
div3.p: --A captain of the 5th Kentucky regiment writes of Kirby Smith:

Before going into the battle at Richmond, Ky., he spent a season alone in his tent in prayer. --When the battle was over, he returned to his tent, and gave thanks to God for the victory.
When at Lexington, Ky., the minister at the Episcopal Church refused to officials on thanksgiving day, and Gen. Smith arose, read a chapter, led in prayer, and finished the services.
In the Kentucky campaign Gen. Smith was the only General who succeeded in his part of the programme.

div4.p: On Sunday morning, Feb. 1st, 1861, of diphtheria, after an illness of three weeks, Kate Beauregard, only child of M E and Virginia Billcott, aged 19 months.
Her funeral will take place from the residence of her father on Cherry street, Sidney, to-day, at 2½ o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.
On Sunday at 4 o'clock, from a gunshot wound, Robert H. Johnston, aged 20 years. He was a member of the Petersburg Grays, 12th Va. regiment, Co. B.
The friends of the family are requested to attend his funeral from his father's residence, corner of Governor and Franklin sts., this day at 3 o'clock.
on February 1st, at 5 o'clock A. M. Ida Jane, the only daughter of Mr. And Mrs. Frederick Meyer, aged 7 weeks.

lg.l: farewell, my Ida, my darling Ida,
around God's bright and dazzling throne
I hope to meet with you.
Weep not for me, my parents dear,
I am gone to rest, you need not fear;
My stay was short, as you may see,

div4.p: The funeral will take place from the residence of Mrs. Susan Baker, on 4th street, one door from Leight, to-day, at 12 o'clock M. The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend.
on Saturday, 31st of January, of pneumonia, Alfred J., only child of A. J. And Sarah A. Vaughan, aged ten months and twenty-five days.

lg.l: Allie, wake, for he who loved thee,
he who died that thou might live--
Waits thy crown of joy to give.
Fare thee well, though woo is bleading
With the tones of earthly love;
Wait thee in the realms above.

div4.p: Petersburg papers please copy. *

At his residence, in Hanover county, at 3 o'clock P. M., on Tuesday, the 27th inst., after a short but painful illness, George Kelly, in the 63d year of his age. He leaves an aged wife and nine children to deplore his loss. *
At the residence of his grandmother, Mrs. A. W. Archer, in Amelia county, of scarlet fever, James Archer, youngest son of John W. and Molile F. Prichett, aged 23 months. *

div3.head: Attempt at murder.--$200 reward.
div3.p:
--The undersigned offer a reward of two hundred Dollars for the apprehension and confinement in any of the jails of this city or of King William county, of a negro named Richard, who on Friday night last, January 30th, made a brutal, and, it is feared, successful, attempt to murder the manager upon their plantation in King William county.
Richard is a small and delicately-formed negro, about 18 or 19 years of age, and is marked on the ride of his head by a scald upon which there is no hair.
He was hired last year to Mr. John D. Quarles, of this city, but ran away, and upon his return stated that he accompanied the Thomas Artillery, of this city, for six months as a servant — He is not doubt at this time making his way to the lines of our army, near Fredericksburg, or is lurking in or near this city.
div3.closer:
P. H. Aylett,
W. R. Aylett,
Richmond, Feb. 2, 1863. fe 2--2t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the camp of the 15th Louisiana regiment, near Gulnee's Station, my boy Nelson.
He is about 5 feet 5 or 6 inches high, dark griffe, rather quick spoken, about 30 years of age. He left camp about three weeks since, and is supposed to be in some of the adjoining camps, or on his way to Richmond.
I will pay the above reward if delivered to me, or for any information that may lead to his recovery.
div3.closer:
Wm. C. Michie,
Capt. Co. G, 15th La Reg't,
Near Guines Station. fe 2--6t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Runaway from my house, in city of Richmond, on the 26th January, my boy Anthony, answers to the name of Toney, is about 13 years old, dark skin, very intelligent, answers promptly when spoken to. I will pay the above reward if taken out of the limits of the city, and delivered to Messrs Hill, Dickinson & Co, or $25 it taken in the city.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--$5 reward offered for a negro man named Tom. He has a blemish about the left eye; is a big stout negro, and about six feet high.
The above reward will be given for his delivery to Mr. E. D. Eacho, on 14th street, near Exchange alley.

div3.head: Runaway or Stolen.
div3.p:
--Some time before Christmas, my negro boy, John, supposed to have been taken off by a Lieutenant of a Louisiana regiment.
He is a yellow boy, very stout, and about 14 or 15 years old. A reward of four hundred Dollars will be given--two hundred dollars for the Boy, and two hundred for the Thief.
Address

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid for an acceptable Substitute by a gentleman residing in Pittsylvania county, to serve in a first class cavalry company.
A good horse will be furnished.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Garlton, Chamberlain & Co.
No. 111 Main street. fe 2--dt*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --I will give a liberal price for one who can come will recommended and over 45 years of age. Call at Messrs Apotts & Harvey's No. 20 Fourteenth street, to-day, between 9 o'clock A. M. and 3 P. M.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Who can furnish satisfactory evidence as to age and character, for whom a liberal price will be paid — a native of one of the Southern States preferred.
Call at Sadler's Hotel, No. 9 Main street, between the hours of 3 and 4 P. M.

div3.head: Substitutes Wanted.
div3.p:
--Two substitutes wanted.
A liberal price will be given.
Apply at the Powhatan Hotel office.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--I wish to employ a Substitute.
One well recommended and over forty-five can obtain a liberal price by applying at E. H. Stokes's, room No. 9, this morning.

div3.head: A Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid for a Substitute who is not to conscription.
Apply to E. D. Eacho, on 14th street, near the Exchange Hotel,

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --For a man over 45 years old, well recommended, a liberal price will be paid.

Also, wanted to sell, several Houses and Lots and a fine, thorough-bred Horse.
He rides and works well, and has been trained to cavalry service.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Dr. Broocks.
Corner of Main and 12th sts. ja 31--3t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For the 15th Regiment Va. Cavalry, for which a good horse, saddle, and all necessary equipments will be furnished and a liberal price paid.
Apply at once at Ward A, General Hospital No. 12, corner of 19th and Franklin streets, between the hours of 9 and 3, till 31st January.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid for a Substitute who is well recommended.
To a native born and man of family preference will be given.
Call at
div3.closer:
Isaac Nordlinger's.
17th st, bet. Main and Franklin. ja 31--2t*

div3.head: Wanted — a Substitute.
div3.p: --The highest price will be paid for a man over 45 years. Call immediately at
div3.closer:
Z. B. Waldon's,
Corner of 8th and Broad sts. ja 31--2t*

div3.head: Headq'rs camp of Instruction, Richmond, Jan. 31, 1863.
div3.p: Thirty Dollars reward each will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of the following Deserters from this camp:
James Morgan, a substitute, 47 years old, gray eyes, light hair, florid complexion, five feet eight inches high, born in Virginia, and by occupation a seamen.
P. Callahan, a substitute, 45 years old, blue eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 5 ½ inches high, born in Mississippi, and by occupation a sailor.
J. W. Gribeen, a substitute, 46 years old, gray eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 5 ½ inches high, born in Ireland and by occupation a laborer.
James Dunn, a substitute 47 years old, blue eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high born in Virginia, and by occupation a laborer.
John Saunders, a substitute, 46 years old, blue eyes, dark hair, florid complexion 5 feet 5 ½ inches high, born in Scotland, and by occupation a laborer.
div3.closer:
By order of Maj. T. G. Peyton.
Jas. E. Heath, Lt and Adj't. fe 2--3t*

div3.head: Camp battery no. 2, January 31, 1863.
div3.p: last Chance for Absentees.--Pursuant to orders issued by Major General G. W. Smith, all members of Company A, 10th Battalion Virginia Volunteers, Heavy Artillery, now absent, are hereby notified that if they report to camp by the 10th day of February no punishment will be inflicted, except the loss of pay for time absent.--Should they not report by the 10th day of February they will be considered deserters, and tried by the new Military Court now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.

closer.signed: Capt. Commd'g Co. A, 10th Batt. Va. Vols.

div3.head: Headq'rs President's guard, February 2d, 1863.
div3.p:
all members of this company now absent must report within 48 hours, or they will be advertised as deserters.
Sick members must send a Surgeon's certificate.

div3.head: Administrator's sale of House-hold Furniture, &c.
div3.p: --Will be sold, on Wednesday next, the 4th day of Feb'y, commencing at 10½ o'clock, at the late residence of Mordecal Garnell, dec'd, corner of Cathorine and Mouroe streets, all the personal property of said decedent, consisting of Chairs, Sideboard, Tables, Carpets, Bads, Bedding, etc. Also, two old negro Men — the one a good sawyer, and the other a gardener, etc.

div3.head: Office R, F. & P. Railroad Co., February 2d, 1863.
div3.p:
Wanted.--A competent Clerk and Agent for this company at Hanover Junction. One not liable to conscription preferred.
None need apply without the most reliable of character and qualifications.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--to Auction and Commission Houses.--A gentleman of many years' experience in the commission and in making up sales and accounts current wishes a Situation in an Auction or Commission House.
A fair salary will be required.
Address "H. M. S, " Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted — board
div3.p:
--By the wise of a soldier now in service, by the week of month, till 1st of May, in some private family within six miles of Richmond.
Advance payment will be made, if required.
Address "L. A. H," stating terms and locality.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --To hire, for the present year or to purchase, a Girl, twelve or fifteen years of age, to mind children and assist in house work.
div3.closer:
C. H. Deffis,
Opposite Metropolitan Hall.
Franklin st. fe 3--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To hire, a Servant Boy, to attend an officer in camp near Fredericksburg.
Good wages paid.
Apply immediately at the office of the Linwood House, 9th and Main streets.

div3.head: Wanted.--a Dituner.
div3.p:
--I wish to employ a first-rate Dituner, to work upon a place eight miles from Richmond.
Apply immediately to
div3.closer:
C. H. Dennis, Franklin st.
Opposite Metropolitan Hall. fe 2--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Situation in come House or Hotel, as Clerk by a youth 16 years of age, who has had some experience.--References given.
Address "C," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An intelligent young Lady to assist in the store.
Best of reference required.
Apply to
